newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: DUTCH CLOSING DEBT MARKET REPORT.
newsitem.headline: DUTCH CLOSING DEBT MARKET REPORT.

text.p: Dutch bonds closed mixed to higher on Wednesday, after a quiet day's trade only ruffled by a new corporate issue.
Most prices rose at the opening but then hardly moved during the rest of the day.
"This was another very quiet day until the Batavia issue. Slowing German M3 growth inspired trade in the morning, but after having digested that, we were slowing down again," one dealer said.

He added the new 6.125 percent December 2006 Batavia Credit Card Corp issue caused a flurry in the market as players switched between Dutch government bonds with more or less the same maturity and the corporate issue.
One dealer said the timing of the new issue came as a surprise, just before the year-end.
Dealers added the Dutch bond market was set for some slow weeks till January, unless the Bundesbank changed its M3 growth target for 1997, compared to this year's four to seven percent.
"It might set a little higher target for 1997 after failing to reach it this year. That might be a reason for some moves (in the bond market) overhere," one dealer said.
He added a BUBA rate hike was less likely but would have a bigger effect on Dutch bonds.
